fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-33125].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
When visiting a Jira Server site using a mobile browser, such as Chrome on an Android device, or Safari on an iOS device, Jira's mobile view does not offer the ability to transition an issue.


h3. Suggested Solution
Allow issues to be transitioned in this view


h3. Why this is important
Mobile view offers benefits to those platforms, it makes sense to offer them at least these basic functions in Jira as a means be able to work on issues when mobile.

h3. Workaround 
It is possible to switch to desktop view to transition, but this is not an ideal experience.



h3. Original description:

If the transition is screen-based, the mobile UI should redirect user to the desktop view of the transition screen (warn the user first) and then complete the transition and return him to mobile view issue screen.
fields.summary: Allow user to transition an issue in Jira from when using the mobile view

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-33124].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
The JIRA Mobile Interface does not allow users to create issues.

h3. Suggested Solution
Allow users to create JIRA issues on the mobile interface. 

h3. Workaround 
# Switch to the Desktop interface on the Mobile device.
# In case JIRA is configured with e-mail integration as per [Creating Issues and Comments from Email|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Creating+Issues+and+Comments+from+Email], create the issue via e-mail.
fields.summary: As a user, I want to be able to create issues using JIRA Mobile

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Required field validation works only on the first Cascading drop-down list

h3. Steps to replicate

# Add a *Select list (cascading)* field
# In the field configuration, add some options for that field
# Make that field required
# Add it to an issue
# Only select the first field from the drop-down
# Save the form

h3. Expected results
You get an error from Jira because the 2nd drop-down was not filled out, and it's required

h3. Actual results
Form saves without errors

h3. Workaround

Use the [Suite Utilities for JIRA|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/5048/jsu-suite-utilities-for-jira?hosting=server&tab=overview] plugin and the "Field Required" workflow validator
* You would add this to the Create Transition and also make the field required
* You need to make the field required so that it will show the red asterisk indicating that it is required
fields.summary: Required field validation works only on the first Cascading drop-down list

fields.description:
Problem:

We have Cascading custom field. This field is required, but we still see "None" value in the list. It should be removed when field is required. 

Same problem is solver on simple drop-down list (https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-7687) but not on Cascading.

Please fix it.
fields.summary: "None" value is displayed in Required Cascading custom field

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-33116].
  {panel}

*Scenarios:*
# The customer JIRA instance have two user account with same email address and one of them is inactive mode. But, JIRA mail handler not able to create an issue for the active user due of using the same email address as of inactive user. 
# in JIRA Cloud, the Mail Handler is configured with a default reporter. There is a disabled user in the Database with the same email address as the sender. The issue is not created because the mail handler matches the disabled user in the database. This also happens with active users that don't have create issue permission and (New in 2016) JIRA Cloud Deleted users that have issues and remain hidden in the database.

h4. Steps to reproduce the problems:
*Scenario 1*
# Create two user (A and B) with same email address.
# Deactivate user A.
# Send an email to the user B email address (which should be the same as A) and send to POP/IMAP server.
# It will get the following warning message from incoming mail log, please see:{noformat}
2013-05-20 15:52:00,382 WARN [test] QuartzWorker-0 ServiceRunner    test test[10001]: Reporter (testing) does not have permission to create an issue. Message rejected.
2013-05-20 15:52:05,334 WARN [test] QuartzWorker-0 ServiceRunner    test test[10001]: Reporter (testing) does not have permission to create an issue. Message rejected.
{noformat}

*Scenario 2*
# Remove application access for a user in JIRA. The user is now disabled.
# Send an email with that email address to a Mail Handler with a "Default Reporter"

h4. Expected behaviour
JIRA creates issues because the user has an option to do so.

h4. Actual behaviour
JIRA doesn't create any issues for the users that have an email address in the database and are either disabled, deleted or without permissions although the Mail Handler allows issue creation with default mail handler or there is another user with that email address.

h4. Workaround
Re-enable users and give correct permissions for issue creation or trick JIRA by renaming users and email addresses:

*1)* Enable inactive/deleted users
Failing email addresses for users that were deleted can be manually re-created from the User Management.
*To detect failing emails:* Set a "Forward Email" address in the mail handler to receive notifications when emails fail and then manually grant access to users so the email is processed.

*Manually fixing inactive and deleted users:*
Scenario 1) Check for duplicate email address:
{code}select lower_email_address from cwd_user group by lower_email_address having count(lower_email_address) > 1;
{code}
Scenario 2) Find Deleted or disabled users:
{code}
select user_name, first_name, last_name, display_name, email_address, active from cwd_user where active = 0 ;
{code}

*Steps for Cloud Support to mass re-enable deleted users:*
# Export deleted users to .csv
{noformat}copy (SELECT user_name AS "Username", first_name AS "First Name", last_name AS "Last Name", user_name AS "Email Address", credential AS "Password" FROM cwd_user where active = 0 and display_name like '%[X]') to '/tmp/users-deleted.csv' csv header;{noformat}
# Remove from the .csv the users that don't cause problems with the emails and don't need to be re-enabled.
# Use user-csv-importer to re-enable users.

*2)* Assign correct permissions to users so they can create issues or Trick JIRA by changing user_name and email_address to a dummy address. Remember that the mail handler matches incoming emails to email_address and user_name.
fields.summary: Mail handler incorrectly matches inactive or deleted users email address when creating an issue
I think it would be useful to have any field, Description, Summary or Comments, show as edited when someone makes changes.
Links to Advanced Searching Functions on Advanced Searching page doesn't go anywhere

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-33112].
  {panel}

As of now, we can only view this activity from the *Activity* tab on the particular issue as per the following to know whether the user creates an issue from the UI:
!create_issue.JPG|thumbnail!

What if we want to monitor issues that were created from email instead? Is it possible to have some sort of *label / tag* to show that the issue was indeed created via email?

As an example:
bq. *admin* created {{TESTONE-22 - Bug 6}} [via email]

The only way to monitor this so far is to check the incoming mail for IMAP / SMTP mail server by looking at the issues that are present from there but of course, this is tedious and what if the email only exists for commenting the issue but the issue was actually created from the UI?
fields.summary: Is there any way to know whether the issue is created from email (via JIRA UI)?
jira

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-33110].

h3. Steps to reproduce
- Create issues with summary containing the words "conf" and "work"
- Search in Issue Navigator with the following JQL:
{noformat}
summary ~ "conf; work"
{noformat}

h3. Actual Results
- No issues are returned

h3. Expected results
- At least the two issues containing the words "conf" and "work" in summary would be returned

(i) The same JQL search works in JIRA 5.0.2
fields.summary: Semicolon JQL operator no longer works in JIRA 5.2
JIRA should validate the JQL on the fly

fields.description:
JIRA Copy feature ( using JIRA to JIRA Copy plugin 3.0 ) failed when JIRA integrated with LDAP.


The problem is reproducible when the following criterias are met:
* JIRA is integrated with LDAP - Delagated LDAP
* The user perform the action (COPY) locally from Project A to project B.


*Steps to reproduce:*
# Setup a new JIRA 5.2.11 and integrate it with LDAP
# Install JIRA to JIRA copy plugin 3.0
# Create 2 projects - Project A and Project B.
# Create one issue in project A.
# Copy the issue by click on Remote Copy {{More Action -> Remote Copy}}.
# The following error is shown. 
{noformat}java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.atlassian.crowd.embedded.impl.IdentifierUtils.toLowerCase(IdentifierUtils.java:42)
	at com.atlassian.cpji.fields.value.CachingUserMapper.getUsersByEmail(CachingUserMapper.java:64)
	at com.atlassian.cpji.fields.value.CachingUserMapper.mapUser(CachingUserMapper.java:95)
	at com.atlassian.cpji.fields.system.AssigneeFieldMapper.mapUser(AssigneeFieldMapper.java:101)
	at com.atlassian.cpji.fields.system.AssigneeFieldMapper.getMappingResult(AssigneeFieldMapper.java:69)
	at com.atlassian.cpji.fields.permission.SystemFieldMappingChecker.getFieldPermission(SystemFieldMappingChecker.java:83)
	at com.atlassian.cpji.components.CopyIssueService.checkFieldPermissions(CopyIssueService.java:257)
	at com.atlassian.cpji.components.remote.LocalJiraProxy.checkPermissions(LocalJiraProxy.java:151)
	at com.atlassian.cpji.action.CopyIssueToInstanceAction.doDefault(CopyIssueToInstanceAction.java:503)
{noformat}

*Finding*
* This problem happened in both JIRA 5.1.8 and JIRA 5.2.11. 
* Tested using normal and administor user, same problem occurred.
* Testing Remote copy feature without LDAP integration, the problem will be disappear. 
* This is not happened in older version of JIRA to JIRA copy plugin during my test using version 3.0-rc1 and 3.0-rc2.
fields.summary: Remote copy issue to another project will break if JIRA integrated with LDAP
JIRA to Programmaticaly disable IE compatibility mode
Remove uninformative upgrade task messages from log output

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-33100].
  {panel}

The attached files display the current help menus which show when opening them in JIRA (large menu) and Confluence (small menu). The instance these screenshot are taken from has only JIRA+Confluence.

These menus are not uniform, and contain information which is not relevant to the user at all.
IE
The JIRA menu contains 4 options which are irrelevant to this instance; Greenhopper Help, Agile Answers, Tempo Online Documentation and Tempo Answers. The Confluence one contains the feed builder and an Available Gadgets option.

Can this menu get changed into something more uniform?
Like, remove product links that are not relevant to the instance.
Place an "available gadgets" link specific for that product
Place an "available products" link pointing towards WAC
Keep the Credits/About/What's New
The Online Help option maybe should point to the KB instead (which would also require some work on the KBs to eventually increase deflection, though this might be an experiment)
fields.summary: Displayed content on Navigation Bar Help Menu

Example of correct (green) JQL syntax for issue search:

See attached the screenshots and the error log.

Thanks,
Roxana DAN

[JIRA 5.2.5 + GH 6.2.1]

h3. Steps to reproduce:

# Focus on 'Description' field in the issue view page.
# Set the input of Windows OS to Hiragana or Katakana.
# Type key 'a', then key 'a'.

Japanese characters 'ああ' have been typed, then character 'あ' will be typed in surplus.

!screenshot.png!

This is occurred on Firefox browser only. IE/Chrome works fine.

Best regards,
Kan Ogawa
fields.summary: Unnecessary Japanese character is typed automatically.

fields.description:
# Set an incorrect base URL for JIRA (for example http://idontexist.com).
# (BUG) Run a search and try to share it. You will end up with a query like: http://idontexist.com/issues/?jql=...

I would assume we would use the context of the incoming request to generate the URL like we do where possible in JIRA (I think we only use the base URL when we don't have requests like with e-mail).

I can see the argument for using the application URL (i.e. when configured correctly, its what the external clients should see). However, we often get support requests that result from bad application URLs and it would be good to avoid any of this load. 

This may be less of an issue now we have the baseURL plugin.
fields.summary: The "Share Dialog" on the issue navigator uses the application base URL rather than the request URL when generating URLS.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-33092].
  {panel}

h3. Steps to Reproduce:
# Create a *Select List* Custom Field;
# Create two additional contexts to the Custom Field;
# Configure the Contexts as described below:
#* *Default Configuration Scheme for Test Custom Field*:
Issue type(s): Global (all issues)
Project(s): Global (all projects)
Options:
#** Option 1
#** Option 2
#** Option 3
\\
#* *Second Configuration Scheme for Test Custom Field*:
Issue type(s): Global (all issues)
Project(s): Project A
Options:
#** Option 2
#** Option 3
\\
#* *Third Configuration Scheme for Test Custom Field*:
Issue type(s): Global (all issues)
Project(s): Project B
Options:
#** Option 1
#** Option 3
#** Option 4
\\
# Go to the *Issue Navigator* and add a criteria for this custom field;
# Select all the options (Option 1, Option 2, Option 3, Option 4)
# Save the search as a filter or refresh the page and see the options again.

h3. Expected Results:
After saving the filter/refreshing the page, JIRA would display the options for the Custom Field as it displays before saving the filter:
!Expected.png|align=center!

h3. Actual Results:
JIRA duplicates the selected options and displays a "{{Value 'yyy' is not valid}}" icon next to the custom field:
!Actual.png|align=center!

*Note:* This also happens with other custom field types such as Radio Buttons.
fields.summary: JIRA Simple Search - Criteria displays 'Value is not Valid'

about rows in the the customfieldvalue table with values for the field but no issue.

I am seeing an instance of this corruption happen about once a week with JIRA 5.2.4, MySQL and a large JIRA instance. No pattern to the custom field type that I can see yet.

This is concerning because it breaks project imports, and also breaks project archiving using the JIRA Archiving Plugin (https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAARCH)

List of plugins:

Copy Date (custom)
CustomWare JIRA Utilities
JIRA Auditor
JIRA Calendar Plugin
JIRA Charting Plugin
JIRA Misc Workflow Extensions
JIRA Project Role Tab
JIRA Subversion plugin
JIRA Suite Utilities
JIRA Toolkit Plugin
Custom Helpdesk
Script Runner
Show Saved Filter With Columns
Template Helper (custom)
valiantys-base-plugin
VertygoSLA - Service Level Agreement
fields.summary: Corrupted data in customfieldvalue

fields.description:
A user can still be assigned to an issue despite having no Assignable User permission in that project. 
However, the criteria is that you must specify the Assignable User permission of the project's permission scheme to include the *Reporter* role. 
Note that a user does not need to be the reporter, (in fact the user does not even need to be in any groups) to be assigned to issues in this project, as long as the *Reporter* role is added to the assignable user permission.

REPLICATION STEPS:
# Install a fresh new JIRA 5.2.11 instance.
# Create a new user, *user_a*. Remove all groups from this user.
# Create a new project.
# Modify the project's permission scheme to include the *Reporter* role into the *Assignable User* permission.
# Now create a new issue. In the "Assignee" field, *type in* the username *user_a* in full. Click on the Create button.
# Observe that the issue is created successfully, and the user is really assigned to the issue.

OTHER NOTES:
# Typing the username of the user into the Assignee field does not auto-complete, however clicking on "Assign" or "create issue" button will still successfully assign the user.
fields.summary: User can still be assigned to issues despite having no Assignable User permission

fields.description:
Steps to Reproduce:
1. Perform a search.
2. Resize the browser window to a smaller width.
3. Hover over the pagination links. Notice the tipsy to be out of alignment. 

In some case the the tipsy overlaps with the page links and hence making it impossible to navigate to the next the page of the issue search result.
fields.summary: The Page tipsy on the issue navigator lose alignment on the small browser windows

fields.description:
When creating an issue in JIRA where multiple field configurations schemes are used, when switching from one project to another the attributes of the original project/issue type for field configurations are not releasing to the new field configuration for the new project/issue type. I have found that I need to refresh the screen to get the changes to take. I have seen this in a couple different instances. 

Scenario #1: Field config scheme for issue type "Benchmark Target" has a short java code in the description of the summary field which renders text in the summary field. It is specific to this field configuration, applied only to this issue type. When switching from the project this issue is in to another project and another issue type, the java code persists and the string of text is rendered in the summary field. However if I refresh the create issue window, it goes away.

Scenario #2: Pretty much the reverse of this, when moving to the project with the java code in the description for Summary in its field config, the code does not come up because the create issue is still attached to the old projects field configuration. If I refresh, then the Summary field string of text appears from the description based java code.

It appears that when switching from project to project in the create issue window, there is not a clean break from the old field configuration scheme to the new one. Even when the issue types are not the same in each project.
fields.summary: When switching projects in create issue, field configurations are not disassociating

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-33054].
  {panel}

{panel:title=Atlassian Update – 5-Dec-2018|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9|titleBGColor=#ebf2f9|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hello, everyone! We have been performed tests and found that we are no longer able to replicate this behavior in the latest Jira 7.12.3. Since all the confirmed versions so far for this issue have been in EOL versions, and we are not able to reproduce in Jira 7.12.3, we will proceed to close this request, for now, and re-evaluate in case we are able to confirm the issue still exists in any newer versions, which will be done by our support team.

Best regards,
René Chiquete - JAC Champion
{panel}

h3. Summary
The Create Issue (AJAX) dialog incorrectly shows {{Some issue types are unavailable due to incompatible field configuration and/or workflow associations}}.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
h4. Method 1
# Navigate to {{[jira.atlassian.com|https://jira.atlassian.com]}}
# Click on the *Create* button to create an issue.

h4. Method 2
# Download and restore [^reproducible.zip];
# Access it using the following credentials:
{noformat}
username: matheus
password: matheus
{noformat}
# Click on the *Create* button to create an issue.
# If the above doesn't reproduce the behavior:
## type {{DEMO-1}} in the search field;
## Click on 'Edit' on the issue;
## Close the Edit issue dialog;
## Open the 'Create' dialog again.

h4. Method 3
# Setup your JIRA instance so that you have a project/issuetype/workflow combination that shows this warning when you edit an issue (for the issue type field)
# Edit an issue so that this warning is shown (using the quick edit dialog)
# Then try to create a new issue. The warning will be shown in the quick create dialog
# Right click on create issue and open it in a new tab. The warning will not be shown which is the correct behavior.

h3. Expected Results
The create issue AJAX dialog would show all projects and issue types available without any warnings.

h3. Actual Results
The create issue AJAX dialog does show all projects and issue types available, but shows the following message:
bq. Some issue types are unavailable due to incompatible field configuration and/or workflow associations

This can be seen in the attached video: [^behavior.mp4]

h3. Workaround
There is a KB in which there are workarounds mentioned in case you want to remove this message from showing in the create issue screen: [Some issue types are unavailable due to incompatible field configuration and/or workflow associations|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirakb/some-issue-types-are-unavailable-due-to-incompatible-field-configuration-and-or-workflow-associations-278692623.html].
* This message is expected in the Issue edit screen.

h3. Original Description
{quote}
{panel}
To reproduce:
* Setup your JIRA instance so that you have a project/issuetype/workflow combination that shows this warning when you edit an issue (for the issue type field)
* Edit an issue so that this warning is shown (using the quick edit dialog)
* Then try to create a new issue. The warning will be shown in the quick create dialog
* Right click on create issue and open it in a new tab. The warning will not be shown which is the correct behavior.

The full warning is: "Some issue types are unavailable due to incompatible field configuration and/or workflow associations."

The root cause is in the FieldHtmlFactoryImpl class.  It has a mutable static final Map of DISPLAY_PARAMS that's passed into both the getCreateHtml() and getEditHtml() field methods. If any of the fields modify this map and set certain params (such as "restrictedSelection") then these params will be passed to any subsequent calls as well until the server is restarted so that this map is restored to its inital state!

We should probably make this map immutable and create mutable copies everytime we call getEditHtml()/getCreateHtml().  Now if only I knew the idiot who wrote this code ;)...
{panel}
{quote}

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

# Create a new search and add the "Due Date" clause.
# Select "Due in next" 12 hours and not overdue. 
# (BUG) Switch to advanced. Note the JQL is {{due <= 12h}} which includes issues which are overdue. The query needs to be {{due <= 12h and due >= "0"}} (NOTE: The quotes are important, that is {{due <= 12h and due >= 0}} will not work).
# Switch back into simple mode.
# (BUG) Select "Due in next" 12 hours and overdue. This query makes no sense because something cannot be due in the future and overdue. 
# (BUG) Switch to advanced mode. The query is wrong {{due <= 12h and due >="0"}}. The query should actually be {{due <= "0" and due <= 12h}} which will never match anything.
fields.summary: DUE date searcher is giving incorrect results when asking for issues "not overdue"

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-33048].
  {panel}

There are many times when our users want to query all the issues for the prior month or week and want to save that to a filter.  The current model only allows that to be done on a fixed date basis.  It would be nice to add the following two functions to JQL to make this easier to accomplish:
startOfLastMonth()
startOfLastWeek()

Maybe even the following as well:
startOfLastYear()

That way users can write queries like:
.... and created >= startOfLastMonth() and created < startOfMonth()

These would be very useful when doing metrics, and I would think would be very simple to implement.

Please consider adding these functions.

Thanks.
fields.summary: Additional date functions in JQL
Inline Thumbnail images should open to overlay, same as in the attachments area

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce*
* Import issues that were originally set to Unassigned (The option of Allow Unassigned Issues is set to ON)
* Perform a bulk edit of issues
* After the bulk edit process is completed, it created a new user called Unassigned

*Expected behavior*

* The issues should be assigned to the system Unassigned rather than the Unassigned user that was created during the import of issues

*Actual behavior*
* The system assigned back the issues to the Unassigned user that was created and even after the original issues were updated to have NULL assignee, it clashes with the system Unassigned, which eventually causes the removal of the created Unassigned user to be halted.
* The system did not recognize all the issues had a NULL assignee rather than doing what appeared to be a string match on Unassigned

The user was trying to perform a bulk edit of 41 issues which were intended to be left as _Unassigned_. When the process was completed, it somehow created an _Unassigned_ user. When the user tries to delete the user, he was told that it is not possible because there were ~6000 issues assigned to it.

Diving into the database to check on what could be the reason, the user saw that the {{jiraissue}} table has issues with {{ASSIGNEE="unassigned"}}, whereby the _Unassigned_ issues have the {{ASSIGNEE=NULL}}.

After updating the 41 issues to have the assignee of {{NULL}}, the user was still unable to delete the _Unassigned_ user from the *Users* page as it says that there are still ~6000 issues assigned to it.

The *workaround* that we managed to figure out was the following:
# Create User A and User B
# Turn off email notifications
# Bulk assign all open unassigned tickets to User A
# Bulk open all closed unassigned tickets and assign to User B
# Delete the _Unassigned_ user
# Change all the tickets assigned to User A to blank value
# Change all the tickets assigned to User B to blank value and close them
# Turn on email notifications again

It worked and the following was the customer's feedback on the issue that we were facing:
{quote}
I always understood why the "unassigned" user was created. I think the main problem is how the system differentiates between this and the system unassigned function or NULL assignee.

Most notably, I could see in the jiraissue table the imported issues all had an assignee of "unassigned", which was expected as that user was created during the import. However, I was able to delete this value through the Jira UI, which should then have assigned the issues to the system unassigned function. I could see these changes were reflected in the database, as subsequently to the change each issue had an assignee of NULL (ie system unassigned rather than user "unassigned").

What I found odd was that that data didn't seem to be honoured when trying to delete the user - somewhere else in the system it was doing a comparison which I don't believe was correct - it should've recognised all the issues had a NULL assignee rather than doing what appeared to be a string match on "Unassigned".
{quote}

Perhaps there might be some explanation to this?
fields.summary: Unassigned user removal
https://jira.atlassian.com/500page.jsp

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-33036].
  {panel}

On the documentation of the JIRA Charting Plugin (link below), there are methods explains about how to add the custom field, however it prones to customer having adding the incorrect field instead. To improve this, the method should be updated with a screenshot so that customer can have better understanding on which custom field type to add and which searcher to be used.

* https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/wiki/display/JCHART/JIRA+Charting+Plugin

*Original Text*
{quote}
4 .Go to Administration > Custom Fields and add a new custom field of the type Date of First Response. Do not add the field to any (transition) screens.
** Warning: make sure the _searcher is set to "Date Picker" (bonus: this means you can now search and filter by date of the first comment!)

5. Go to Administration > Custom Fields and add a new custom field of the type Time in Status. Do not add the field to any (transition) screens.
** Warning: make sure the searcher is set to "Free Text Searcher" (NOTE: you will not want to put this field on any screens as the data it stores is not in human readable format)
{quote}

*Proposed Change*
4 .Go to Administration > Custom Fields and add a new custom field of the type Date of First Response. Do not add the field to any (transition) screens.
!dateoffirstresponse.png!
** Warning: make sure the _searcher is set to "Date Picker" (bonus: this means you can now search and filter by date of the first comment!)
!dateoffirstresponsesearcher.png!

5. Go to Administration > Custom Fields and add a new custom field of the type Time in Status. Do not add the field to any (transition) screens.
!timeinstatus.png!
** Warning: make sure the searcher is set to "Free Text Searcher" (NOTE: you will not want to put this field on any screens as the data it stores is not in human readable format)
!searchtimein.png!
fields.summary: Update JIRA Charting Plugin Documentation to Have Screenshot on Adding Customfield

fields.description:
{{jira.permission.assignable.group}} workflow property does not work correctly. Even if a user is not in the specified group to have an issue assignable to him, he can still be assigned although his username does not show up in the Assignee drop-down list.

h4. Steps to reproduce
# Create a new user (test) and add him to {{jira-developers}} group
# Copy the default JIRA workflow, add a workflow property to _Open_ step as follows (remember to publish draft):
{noformat}jira.permission.assignable.group = jira-administrators{noformat}
!workflow_properties1.PNG|thumbnail!
# Ensure Project A is using the default Permission Scheme which has _Assignable User_ permission granted to {{Project Roles(Developers)}}
# Ensure Project A is using the default Roles, where Project Roles(Developers) contains {{jira-developers}} group
# Associate Copy of default JIRA workflow to Project A
# Create a new issue in Project A and try to assign it to the newly created user (test): the user won't appear in drop-down list but if you type the full username (test) and click _Assign_ button, the user can still be assigned
!workflow_properties2.png|thumbnail!
# Remove the {{jira.permission.assignable.group}} from the workflow and publish draft. Try to assign again on the same issue: the user now appears in drop-down list as expected
!workflow_properties3.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Workflow properties on JIRA permission allow unassignable users to be assigned

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-33033].
  {panel}

Here is the use case: We have a significant number of Jira users which do ask  do ask to create new projects for even if they work on the same product.

So we ended up with a configuration like this:
* {{CA}} - Main product issue list
* {{CP}} - CA Planning
* {{CR}} - CA Change Requests
* {{PR}} - CA Product Requirements
* {{EA}} - CA Engineering Activity

And there is pressure for creating new ones too. Obviously any jira administrator will tell that this is wrong, as it will create problems, like:

* keeping project configuration updated, components, versions, roles or permission will always be unsynced.
* inability to properly create hierarhic dependencies in GH (you can have epic > story > task only inside the same project)... and in our case we ca CP issues that do have CA ones as subtasks (we use issue links instead, as this is not possible).

Now, the main blocked here is that people do want to be able to knwo what kind of issue type is based on the issue-key.

I do have to confess that I fully understand them, it's quite important to be able to distinguish between them, you cannot always imagine that people do know the meaning of each number.

From the implementation point of view this could be achieved by having some kind of aliases for the project keys like CA=CP=CR=... 

As a note, there is no need to have separate numbering for the issues, it is perfectly OK to share a single sequence numbering. Basically it would not matter if someone writes CA-1234 or CP-1234, it will go to the same issue.

As a note: still when you see an issue, you should see it listed using its own key ( assuming that you have CP-1234 and you search for it using CA-1234, jira should return CP-1234). This seems to be something that could be implemented using current redirection (used when you move issues between projects).

Update: an alternative to this would be to have something like, PROJ-XX-1234 or PROJ-YY-1234 that would allow people to distinguish between different issue types, without having to read/specify the description.
fields.summary: Ability to have different issue keys for different issue types in Jira
Profile image never shown

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-33031].
  {panel}

For Bamboo we use URLs like below to display JIRA issues in Bamboo

bq. https://extranet.atlassian.com/jira/sr/jira.issueviews:searchrequest-xml/temp/SearchRequest.xml?jqlQuery=project%3D%22BDEV%22+AND+issuekey+IN%28BDEV-2400%2CBDEV-2401%29&tempMax=100&field=summary&field=type&field=status&field=link&field=assignee&field=fixVersions

which works fine, however if an issue key is invalid or an issue has been deleted, a 400 error is returned, even though there is one issue that is valid.

bq. https://extranet.atlassian.com/jira/sr/jira.issueviews:searchrequest-xml/temp/SearchRequest.xml?jqlQuery=project%3D%22BDEV%22+AND+issuekey+IN%28BDEV-2400%2CBDEV-24019999%29&tempMax=100&field=summary&field=type&field=status&field=link&field=assignee&field=fixVersions

It'd be great for us to be able to pass in a field like "issueKeyValidate=false" that would disable issueKey validation, and just try to return anything that it matches, even if the value may be invalid.

You might even want to extend this flag to be "dataKeyValidate=false" so that you could also ignore validation for things like version names
fields.summary: Issuekey in JQL search should have an option to not fail if issuekey doesn't exist

fields.description:
Custom field allows user to configure additional context if necessary. However, add additional context would caused existing select list data value to be loss after issue update as the optionid referred was different.

This may have caused minor data loss or serious data loss if user didn't aware of the missing values of the custom field. The problem seems to affect only custom field that using optionid but not stringvalue(eg. text field).

h4. Step to reproduce:
# Create a custom field(eg. select list A) and associate to all projects
# Create few option for the field(eg. 1,2,3)
# Reindex JIRA
# Update one jira issue of Project A with any value in the select list
# Create an additional configuration context for select list A.
# Configure the exact same value as the global context and associate to the specifiec project(eg. Project A).
# Reindex JIRA.
# Go to the issue edit screen, simply add a comment and the select list value would be missing.

In database level, additional optionid was created for the new context(should be intended). After update the issue with a comment, JIRA would smart enough to detect the  of the select list and remove from the customfieldvalue table.

h4. Note:
The value only would be missing if update through the edit screen, workflow and the field must presented in the screen only. The same problem will not happen to inline edit purpose on other field.

h4. Suggestion:
* A warning message if customer are adding an additional context to warn them about existing data loss.
* Implement mechanism to allow map existing option value to their new option value with a peace of mind.

h4. Few Workaround:
# Rollback to prevent any data loss
# Performing search and manually update the field value through bulk change.
# Remove the additional configuration context to prevent further data loss and perform bulk change for the issues that lose the values.
fields.summary: Additional configuration context caused missing value for field with optionid
Hercules for customers installations.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-33019].
  {panel}

*Symptom*:
* restoring XML to JIRA 5.2.11 or JIRA 6.0 rc1
* JIRA throws the following error immediately when trying to restore an XML backup data:
{code}
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at java.util.AbstractCollection.addAll(AbstractCollection.java:303)
	at com.atlassian.jira.imports.project.util.XMLEscapeUtil.unicodeInPlaceEncode(XMLEscapeUtil.java:201)
	at com.atlassian.jira.imports.project.util.XMLEscapeUtil.unicodeInPlaceEncode(XMLEscapeUtil.java:154)
{code}

*Steps to Reproduce:*
# Create an issue that has the character 𠡬 as a summary or description
# Create an XML backup
# Restore the newly created backup or perform a project import
# The steps will result in an NPE

(i) This is not reproducible when restoring the same XML backup data into JIRA 5.2.10

*Root cause*
* invalid characters in the XML backup data

*Workaround*
* fix the data using the XML cleaner on the entities.xml before importing the clean XML backup data . The guide available at [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Removing+invalid+characters+from+XML+backups]
* Detail workaround steps at https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/Project+Import+will+lead+to+NPE
* Upgrade to JIRA 6.0.1
fields.summary: NullPointerException While Restoring JIRA Data If the XML Backup contains the character 𠡬

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When using the JQL function membersOf it's possible to return invalid results if the user is a member of the group being selected in one user directory, but not the current one. For example:

* User {{captain.planet}} in the JIRA Internal Directory (JIT) is a member of the group {{eco-warrior}}.
* That user {{captain.planet}} is *not* a member of that group in the Active Directory (AD).
* Active Directory is above JIRA Internal Directory, so the user is referenced from AD rather than the JIT.
* The {{membersOf("eco-warrior")}} JQL will return issues as if that user was in the group.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Add a user to the JIT and AD (e.g.: {{captain-planet}}).
# Give them a group in the JIT and not the AD (or the other way around), for example {{eco-warrior}}.
# Move the user directory that they are *not* a member of the group to the top.
# Create an issue with them as the reporter.
# Run the following JQL:
{noformat}
reporter = captain.planet and reporter in membersOf("eco-warrior")
{noformat}

h3. Expected Results

The issue is not returned as they are not a member of that group.

h3. Actual Results

The issue is returned, as the other User Directory has them in that group.

h3. Notes

This can be worked around by:

# Swapping the order of the user directories.
# Removing the user from the group.
# Restoring the original order.
fields.summary: JQL function membersOf returns incorrect results if the user has groups in another user directory

Hello
I work as a security researcher and I believe I've managed to break into your Jira systems and get a full access license using an evaluation license
I reversed the code and hacked it to pass the evaluation license as a full one
I've decompiled the JIRA classes located the license class and patched the license checking method to pass the evaluation license as if it's a full license
I may suggest adding some obfuscation to the code
Thanks
